sen.j: 天香山命（あめのかぐやまのみこと/あまの-）は、日本の神 (神道)である。
sen.e: Amenokaguyama no mikoto was the Japanese god (Shinto religion).
Amenokaguyama no mikoto was the Japanese god (Shinto religion).
Amenokaguyama no mikoto was the Japanese god (Shinto religion).

sen.j: 「天香語山命」、「天賀吾山命」等とも書かれるため、「あめ（ま）のかごやまのみこと」とも読む。
sen.e: It was sometimes written as '天香語山命' or '天賀吾山命,' so it could also read 'Ame(ma)nokagoyama no mikoto.'
sen.cmt: 漢字表記が焦点となっているため、訳文に漢字を残しました。
sen.e: It was sometimes written as '天香語山命' or '天賀吾山命,' so it could also read 'Ame(ma)nokagoyama no mikoto.'
It was sometimes written as '天香語山命' or '天賀吾山命,' so it could also read 'Ame(ma)nokagoyama no mikoto.'

sen.j: 『旧事本紀』によれば、天照大神の孫神であるニギハヤヒ（天火明命）と、天道日女命（あめのみちひめ-）との間に生まれた神（天照太神の曾孫神）である。
sen.e: According to "Kujihongi"(Japanese History), he was the god (great grandchild god of Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess) born between Nigihayahi (Ame no Hoakari), the grandchild god of Amaterasu Omikami, and Amenomichihime no mikoto.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: According to "Kujihongi"(Japanese History), he was the god (great grandchild god of Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess) born between Nigihayahi (Ame no Hoakari), the grandchild god of Amaterasu Omikami, and Amenomichihime no mikoto.

According to "Kujihongi" (Japanese History), he was the god (great grandchild god of Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess)) born between Nigihayahi (Ame no Hoakari), the grandchild god of Amaterasu Omikami, and Amenomichihime no mikoto.

sen.j: 尾張氏等の祖神とされ、物部氏等の祖神である宇摩志摩治命（うましまぢ-）とは母神を異にする兄弟神となっている。
sen.e: He was soshin (ancestor honored as god) of Owari clan and was the half brother god of Umashimaji no mikoto who was soshin of Mononobe clan.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He was soshin (ancestor honored as god) of Owari clan and was the half brother god of Umashimaji no mikoto who was soshin of Mononobe clan.
He was soshin (ancestor honored as god) of Owari clan and was the half brother god of Umashimaji no mikoto who was soshin of Mononobe clan.

sen.j: 『新撰姓氏録』にも見え、後裔氏族として尾張氏（左京神別等）を始め、伊福部氏（左京神別下）・六人部氏（山城神別）・津守氏（摂津神別）等を挙げている。
sen.e: He was appeared in "Shinsen Shojiroku" (Newly Compiled Register of Clan Names and Titles of Nobility) and cited Owari clan (stated under the category of Sakyo Shinbetsu (clans branched out of a family of god in the Eastern Capital Offices)), Ifukube clan (stated under the category of Sakyo Shinbetsu ge), Mutobe clan (stated under the category of Yamashiro Shinbetsu) and Tsumori clan (stated under the category of Settsu Shinbetsu).

He appeared in the "Shinsen Shojiroku" (Newly Compiled Register of Clan Names and Titles of Nobility) and cited Owari clan (stated under the category of Sakyo Shinbetsu (clans branched out of a family of god in the Eastern Capital Offices)), Ifukube clan (stated under the category of Sakyo Shinbetsu ge), Mutobe clan (stated under the category of Yamashiro Shinbetsu) and Tsumori clan (stated under the category of Settsu Shinbetsu).

He appeared in the "Shinsen Shojiroku" (Newly Compiled Register of Clan Names and Titles of Nobility) and cited Owari clan (stated under the category of Sakyo Shinbetsu (clans branched out of a family of god in the Eastern Capital Offices)), Ifukube clan (stated under the category of Sakyo Shinbetsu ge), Mutobe clan (stated under the category of Yamashiro Shinbetsu) and Tsumori clan (stated under the category of Settsu Shinbetsu).

sen.j: 『旧事本紀』の「天神本紀」には、饒速日尊の天孫降臨に従った32柱の1柱に数えられたとある。
sen.e: In 'Tenjin hongi' (the original record of the heavenly deity) of "Kujihongi," he was counted as one of thirty two gods who obeyed tensonkorin (the descent to earth of the grandson of the sun goddess) by Nigihayahi no mikoto.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In 'Tenjin hongi' (the original record of the heavenly deity) of "Kujihongi," he was counted as one of thirty two gods who obeyed tensonkorin (the descent to earth of the grandson of the sun goddess) by Nigihayahi no mikoto.

In 'Tenjin hongi' (the original record of the heavenly deity) of "Kujihongi," he was counted as one of thirty two gods who obeyed tensonkorin (the descent to earth of the grandson of the sun goddess) by Nigihayahi no mikoto.

sen.j: 「天孫本紀」では、紀伊国の熊野邑（和歌山県新宮市が比定地になっている）に住み、別名を「手栗彦命（たくりひこ-）」、または「高倉下命」というとあり、以下「記紀」に載せる「高倉下」の伝承と同じ内容を記す（詳しくは高倉下を参照）。
sen.e: In 'Tenson hongi,' it said that he lived in Kumano village, Ki Province (Shingu City, Wakayama Prefecture is its presumed location), another name was '手栗彦命' (Takurihiko no mikoto) or '高倉下命' (Takurihiko no mikoto), and the following was the same contents of tradition in 'Takakuraji' of 'kiki' (the Kojiki and Nihonshoki)(see Takakuraji for details).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処漢字が焦点となっているため、訳文に漢字を残しました。
sen.e: In 'Tenson hongi,' it said that he lived in Kumano village, Ki Province (Shingu City, Wakayama Prefecture is its presumed location), another name was '手栗彦命' (Takurihiko no mikoto) or '高倉下命' (Takurihiko no mikoto), and the following was the same contents of tradition in 'Takakuraji' of 'kiki' (the Kojiki and Nihonshoki)(see Takakuraji for details).

In 'Tenson hongi,' it said that he lived in Kumano village, Kii Province (Shingu City, Wakayama Prefecture is its presumed location), another name was '手栗彦命' (Takurihiko no mikoto) or '高倉下命' (Takurihiko no mikoto), and the following was the same contents of tradition in 'Takakuraji' of 'kiki' (the Kojiki and Nihonshoki) (see Takakuraji for details).

sen.j: また、新潟県の彌彦神社の社伝に、神武天皇の大和国平定後、勅命を受け越国を平定、開拓に従事したと伝える（詳しくは彌彦神社を参照）。
sen.e: Also, in the biography of Iyahiko-jinja Shrine in Nigata Prefecture, it described that he was engaged in subjugation and reclamation of Koshi Province by receiving the Imperial order after Emperor Jinmu subjugated Yamato Province (see Iyahiko-jinja Shrine for details).

Also, in the biography of Iyahiko-jinja Shrine in Nigata Prefecture, it described that he was engaged in subjugation and reclamation of Koshi Province by receiving the Imperial order after Emperor Jinmu subjugated Yamato Province (see Iyahiko-jinja Shrine for details).

Also, in the biography of Iyahiko-jinja Shrine in Niigata Prefecture, it described that he was engaged in subjugation and reclamation of Koshi Province by receiving the Imperial order after Emperor Jinmu subjugated Yamato Province (see Iyahiko-jinja Shrine for details).

tit.j: 天香語山命を祀る主な神社
tit.e: Major shrines where Amenokaguyama no mikoto was enshrined
